Subject: Article Documenting How Natural Selection is Not Good at Choosing At
 Least One of Its Own Parameters (Mutation Rate)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=tf50GeI1U35ZH5r0nr6k_38_bxlZk-pptiTd0wVjAcdrS1_uIGxU
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all-

A while back we had a discussion about whether natural selectio=
n is good at
choosing its own parameters. Many people assume that it would =
be beneficial
to evolve the parameters of a run (e.g. mutation rate, crosso=
ver rate,
etc.). After having done some research in the area I have conclud=
ed that it
does not work well.

When I expressed this view previously, some=
 of you were very skeptical. At
that point, I promised to share a manuscrip=
t that investigates the issue
once it was published.

That manuscript final=
ly came out yesterday in the journal PLoS Computational
Biology. I am rathe=
r excited because they chose it for the cover of the
September issue. 

You=
 can see it here:
www.ploscompbiol.org

Clune, et. al. =B3Natural Selection=
 Fails to Optimize Mutation Rates for
Long-Term Adaptation on Rugged Fitnes=
s Landscapes.=B2

I am interested to see what you think. In particular, I w=
ould like to hear
from those of you that were skeptical of my claim. Do you=
 still feel that
evolution can manage itself in light of this work? Note: I=
 recognize that
this paper only covers mutation rates. However, the mutatio=
n rate is one of
the most important parameters. Furthermore, I think simila=
r issues will
arise with other parameters that result in the perturbation o=
f genomes (e.g.
crossover type and rate).


PS. PLoS allows readers to rate=
 articles. If you enjoyed the article, and
have a second, please rate it hi=
ghly. I would really appreciate it!

PPS. If you are reading this email aft=
er October 25th or so, here is a
direct link to the article.

http://www.pl=
oscompbiol.org/doi/pcbi.1000187

PPPS. I have another paper that found that=
 evolving parameters did not work
tremendously well. That paper covered mor=
e than just mutation rates. You can
check that out here:

https://www.msu.e=
du/~jclune/publications/CluneEtAl-meta-GAs.pdf


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digita=
l Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
